docs.lead_paragraph: KAE LOESCH-JAMES, a credit analyst in Wilmington, Del., has spent a small fortune on weight-loss and fitness products over the years. She paid $100 to join a weight-loss group, $500 for a personal trainer, $98 for several months at a circuit-training program and more than $200 on videos, books and tummy-toning gadgets. Her investments did little to trim the 50 pounds she had been trying to lose, and she blamed her hectic schedule, in part.

headline.main: Paths to Better Health (On the Boss's Nickel)

docs.abstract: Companies are becoming more aggressive in encouraging employees to lose weight, hoping to reduce absenteeism and disabilities, improve productivity and hold down cost of health care; offer such options as onsite counseling from nutritionists, informational Web sites, cooking classes and group weight-loss programs like Weight Watchers; employer-sponsored programs are cheaper for participants than going it alone, and at least one study has shown them to be more effective; incentives offered to employees of AstraZeneca International, HealthPartners, Dole Food Co, Duke University and Blue Cross Blue Shield of Western New York noted; photo (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: BLUE CROSS BLUE SHIELD OF WESTERN NEW YORK

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a big rebound in hiring in the last few months, President Bush has been unable to translate the economic improvement into political benefit, leaving Republicans increasingly anxious that the White House might let slip away its best chance to counter the bad news from Iraq. The creation of nearly 900,000 new jobs in the last four months -- a development that might otherwise have redefined the race in Mr. Bush's favor -- has been largely crowded out of the electorate's psyche by images from Iraq of the abuse of prisoners and the deaths of American troops, said Republican elected officials, pollsters and strategists.

headline.main: Economic Signs Point Up; Bush's Ratings Do Not

docs.abstract: Pres Bush has been unable to translate economic improvement into political benefit, leaving Republicans increasingly anxious that White House might let slip away its best chance to counter bad news from Iraq; Republican officials, pollsters and strategists say creation of 900,000 jobs in last four months has been largely crowded out of electorate's psyche by images from Iraq of abuse of prisoners and deaths of American troops; Labor Dept figures show that unemployment rate fell in April in 11 of 18 states most hotly contested by Bush and Sen John Kerry; rate rose in 4 states, including Ohio, most pivotal of swing states; graphs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Despite a big rebound in hiring in the last few months, President Bush has been unable to translate the economic improvement into political benefit, leaving Republicans increasingly anxious that the White House might let slip away its best chance to...

docs.lead_paragraph: A partnership of about 150 obstetrician-gynecologists in Connecticut announced this week that they planned to add a $500 surcharge to each pregnant woman's bill starting in September. By announcing the surcharge, the group hopes to influence lawmakers to pass ''meaningful reforms'' to reduce the cost of malpractice insurance, said Nancy P. Bernstein, president and chief executive of the partnership, Women's Health Connecticut. The Fairfield County Medical Association, a professional organization representing almost 2,000 physicians in every medical specialty, also announced a position on surcharges: If doctors want to charge patients a fee for items or services not covered by insurance -- such as phoning in prescriptions after hours -- they should, said Mark S. Thompson, the association's executive director.

headline.main: Pushing Insurance Reform With a $500 Surcharge

docs.abstract: About 150 obstetrician-gynecologists belonging to Women's Health Connecticut plan to place $500 surcharge on bills of pregnant women starting in September in effort to pressure state lawmakers to reduce cost of malpractice insurance; Fairfield County Medical Association encourages its 2,000 members to charge patients for services not covered by insurance; Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal says that under physicians' contract agreement with insurance providers, enrollees in state or private insurance plans cannot be billed for any sums beyond what insurance company would pay, excluding deductibles and co-payments (M)
